title: 105_hr3534
content: The Act may be cited as the "Mandates Information Act of 1998" and includes findings. The Congress finds that private sector mandates can have negative effects on consumers, workers, and small businesses, including higher prices, lower wages, and hiring disincentives. The Act aims to improve Congress' deliberation on private sector mandates by providing complete information and ensuring focused deliberation on effects. It also seeks to help Congress differentiate between mandates that harm or benefit consumers, workers, and small businesses. The Act aims to enhance Congress' understanding of the impact of Federal private sector mandates on consumers, workers, and small businesses, including effects on prices. The joint resolution focuses on analyzing the impact of Federal private sector mandates on consumer prices, worker wages, benefits, employment opportunities, hiring practices, expansion, and profitability of businesses with 100 or fewer employees. The Budget Act of 1974 is amended to limit points of order under certain conditions. Threshold amounts for bills increasing Federal private sector mandates are also specified. The Budget Act of 1974 is amended to limit points of order under certain conditions related to Federal private sector mandates. Threshold amounts for bills increasing mandates are specified. The Budget Act of 1974 is amended to limit points of order related to Federal private sector mandates by removing the term "intergovernmental" in various clauses. Threshold burden amounts for bills increasing mandates are also specified. The Budget Act of 1974 is amended to limit points of order related to Federal private sector mandates by removing the term "intergovernmental" in various clauses and rules of the House of Representatives. This section is enacted by Congress as an exercise of the rulemaking power of the Senate. Congress has the power to make rules for the Senate and House of Representatives, superseding inconsistent rules. Each House can change rules relating to them. The Congressional Budget Office must report on the economic impact of amendments to the Budget Act of 1974 annually. The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 is amended regarding federal intergovernmental mandates. The House of Representatives passed the amendment on May 19, 1998.
